description: The title was cancelled with this issue.
name: Fingers Of Fear

description: He's back! Astro Boy makes his amazing return to comics, paving the way for his exciting feature film debut later this year! It's an all-new Astro Boy adventure, with Astro exploring a strange subterranean kingdom in search of his lost father, encountering weird creatures large and small. But are they friend or foe? Look for the Ashley Wood variant cover!
name: Underground: Issue Number One

volume.name: Astro Boy: The Movie: Official Movie Prequel

description: Astro Boy's return to comics continues, in preparation for his blockbuster feature film debut later this year! Astro begins to explore the strange subterranean world miles below the earth's crust, and soon finds himself caught in the middle of a brutal civil war! Look for the Ashley Wood variant cover!
name: Underground: Issue Number Two

volume.name: Astro Boy: The Movie: Official Movie Prequel

description: Who is Dusty Star and what secrets lay in the outlaw streets of Bradstreet, the home of every low-life, scoundrel in the uncharted lands? Dusty begins to gather her posse and follow the clues to solve the mystery of her past and the answers to her future.

Adam Strange faces near omnipotent power, forcing him to seek out Comet for help. However, upon reaching Hardcore Station, Strange is brutally mugged, and Comet deals harshly with an uninvited houseguest. Bizarro arrives on Hardcore Station, but Chief Justice Max is not welcoming him with open arms.
name: Or You Will Be Destroyed!; Always

description:
Malu is found by a soldier, who claims that she is the lost princess of Ormuz. The two journey together to Ormuz and face many challenges.

Synopsis

1. Malu, The Slave Girl

At a party, host Sandra Worth is introduced to archeologist Geoffry Garth. The two hit it off and she asks about his latest quest. He reveals that he was looking for a ring, which happens to look like the ring Sandra is wearing. The two meet the next day to do a test on the ring to see if it has similar magical powers as the ring he was looking for: the mystic ring of Zubran, the signet of the house of Ormuz. As Geoffry performs the incantation, Sandra begins seeing images.

A lone man approaches the ancient city of Tarko. He has a mission and all goes smoothly until a beggar man bumps into him. A ring falls from the man's belongings and guards recognize the seal of Ormuz, a rival province. They immediately seize the man and take him before the king. The man refuses to speak and so the king begins whipping him. Malu, a slave girl, is frightened and spills water on the king's robe. The king orders the man away and turns his ire onto Malu. The man tries to plead mercy for the woman, but he is dragged away.

Later, Malu visits the man in prison after bribing the guard. The man is Garth and he has been looking for Malu, as she is the lost princess of Ormuz (as evidenced by her possession of a ring). The two plan to escape together but are found by palace guards. They are sentenced to death in the lion's pit. As the lions are released, Malu acts on information about a secret door to the arena. She finds it and the lions run out and cause mayhem in the city. The king is eaten. The two follow the lions out and make their escape to Ormuz.

2. The Banquet of Thuz

Soldiers from the city pursue Malu and Garth to the top of a mountain. Garth starts an avalanche that destroys the army of Tarconians. It seems to also have trapped them in a pen of rocks, but Malu finds a cave. That cave turns out to be man-made. They follow it through the mountain and come upon a city. Needing refuge for the night, they enter the city and meet with the king, a man who has taken the rule from a boy king. He promises the two sanctuary but quietly schemes to take Malu for his own.

In their chambers, Malu and Garth are warned about the king's plans to kill Garth and take Malu. They try to escape but are recaptured by guards. The king spares Garth's life only because Malu is willing to marry the king. The king then proposes a party. Wine is brought, but Garth is warned that his goblet has been poisoned. The king grows weary of subterfuge and orders Garth's death. Garth fights back and Malu raises the slaves into insurrection. The king is killed after laying hands on Malu and the rightful boy king begins to reign again. He promises clothes and passage on a caravan to Ormuz.

3. The Curse of Ahmen Ra

This story is text-only and unrelated to the tale of Malu the slave girl. It relates the fate of four men who shirk the threat of a curse as they obtain the jewels of Ahmen Ra. The leader slowly goes mad after the men are shipwrecked and left in a lifeboat. He kills the others and is later killed by a boat that he hoped would save him.

4. Malu the Slave Girl and the Bandits of Tal Azmut

As part of the caravan, Malu tries to get Garth to admit that he loves her. He can't bring himself to say it, only stating that it has been his duty to care for her. She storms off. She gets kidnapped at the edge of camp by bandits of Tal Azmut who seem to know that she has the signet of Ormuz. She is taken to their temple.

Garth discovers that Malu is missing and tries to rally the caravan to pursue the bandits. They refuse because they fear that splitting up will open either party up for attack by any straggler thieves. Garth goes on alone and follows the footprints of Malu's abductors. He ends up at the temple but can't find where the party may have escaped to. He slams a statue in anger and a door opens up. He rushes in and cuts down Malu's guardian; he then cuts her from her bonds. The ruler of Tal Azmut approaches with a company and Garth begins cutting his way through the throng. Things look hopeless but Garth has one last idea. He pushes one statue over the door of the secret door. It works and Malu and Garth ride away on a horse. Garth admits that he will fully perform his duty of holding Malu tight as they ride home.

5. The Slave Market of Manoch

As Garth and Malu approach Ormuz they express how they look forward to taking their relationship to the next level. Inside Ormuz, however, Malu's uncle Phao receives word from Tal Azmut himself (the lone survivor of Garth's assault) that Malu is coming back to take her crown. Phao, it appears, is the reason that Malu was sent away in the first place so that he could take the crown instead. He orders his men to recapture Malu and place her back in the slave market. They do so.

Garth awakens and immediately recognizes Phao's prison. He realizes that Phao must be behind the ills that have fallen Malu in her lifetime. He fakes sick so as to overpower his guard. He then meets with some allies and devises a plan to get Malu back. He dresses up and goes to the slave market and buys her with a kingly sum. She is thrilled to be back in Garth's arms and relishes the thought of literally being his slave girl forever.

Malu is presented to the king and he accepts her as his daughter. Phao enters and demands proof. They have none since she has lost her signet. Things start heating up.

Before anything can be resolved, the ring in the present loses steam and Sandra and Geoffry are left puzzled as to the conclusion. Sandra is adamant that they try again and Geoffry agrees that they can the next day.
name: Malu the Slave Girl

description:
Sandra Worth and Geoffry Garth witness more adventures of Malu and Garth as they try to return to Ormuz from exile. They also see adventures of other princesses throughout time.

Synopsis

Sandra meets Geoffry at his office and the two invoke the powers of signet of Ormuz to see if Malu and Garth escaped the clutches of Phao.

Slave Girl and the Pirates of Abmur

The King of Ormuz is convinced by Phao that Malu is not his daughter. He banishes Malu from his kingdom as allows Phao to set her terms. He also grants Garth to be a slave on Phao's ship. Phao sets sail to desert Malu somewhere in the sea. Garth devises a plan to loosen his bonds and puts the other slaves on alert that they may be escaping soon. He sacrifices his water rations by spilling his supply onto the screw holding him in place in hopes that the wood will rot, allowing his chains to be pulled free. It works and Garth is able to free himself and the slaves as a pirate ship attacks.

Garth finds Phao and chases him atop the ship's mast while the slaves, pirates, and Phao's crew fight below. Phao promises to give up the signet (proof of Malu's heritage) in exchange for his life. Garth is able to grab the ring and Phao attempts to commit suicide while dragging Garth down with him. It doesn't work and Phao falls to his death. Garth slides down the sail and confronts a pirate who wishes to take Malu. The fight is bitter but Garth comes off victorious. He and Malu jump from the now-inflamed ship to test their fate in the depths of the sea.

The Lost Princess

(This is the first of two comic stories relating to a different princess. It has nothing to do with Malu's storyline.)

Two adventurers Ted and Dick explore some of the jungle of the Middle East (?) and get lost. A storm drives the archeologists into a cave. The earth shakes and they fall into a chasm. The air chokes them a little bit but they find a beautiful woman preserved in ice. They cut her out and she reanimates. She is thrilled to find two strong men to help her in her plight during a war. She leads them to her home. The air gets harder to breathe with each step. The princesses land is found and she is distraught that it is already destroyed. She follows the men back to their land. They are glad to breathe fresh air again. They turn and find that the air has reduced their princess into dust.

Malu the Slave Girl in the Tower of Indecision

Malu grows weak as she and Garth look for land. They find a shore as their strength fails them and the rest on the beach for hours. They are found by warriors from Zankhara. The two are brought before Queen Shala and are presented as spies from the sister kingdom of Tirza. The queen orders that Malu become her personal slave. Garth is to be her royal guard. She fancies him.

One afternoon, the queen comes onto Garth and offers him a promotion. Malu walks in as the queen kisses Garth. She mocks the queen for loving on a slave and is taken away by guards. Garth later learns that Malu has been sentenced to the Tower of Indecision. He uses his position in the queen's guard to learn about the tower. It has a spinning floor that gets the prisoner confused. One door leads out to freedom and six doors lead to certain death. He sneaks to the tower to try and free Malu. The queen is wise to his intentions and entraps Garth as well. He and Malu are thrust into the trap portion of the tower.

The floor spins and the two have no idea how to proceed. Garth opens a door and a huge boar rushes out and begins to attack Garth. In a panic, Malu opens another door and a giant lizard rushes out and attacks the boar. Garth and Malu find a way to climb above the harm while the monsters fight. They finally reach safety up high and find an adjacent room containing prisoners. Some guards enter and look for Garth and Malu. They deduce the high point above the prisoners and begin climbing.

The Revel in Vardon Hall

(This is a short story included in the middle of this issue that has nothing to do with the events told in the comic form.)

This story relates the tale of a man who accepts a dare to sleep in a haunted manor. He is beset by ghosts and he plays a concert for them. He escapes and the house is burned to the ground.

The Flame Goddess

(This is the second of two comic stories relating to a different princess. It has nothing to do with Malu's storyline.)

Two archeologists, Cliff and Neal, finally find the lost Peruvian city of Chicalmo. It isn't dead, though, but very much alive. The men are taken captive by the indigenous people.

Neal's sister Shalia awakens from a dream that seems all-too real. She knows her brother is in danger and makes her way to Peru. She learns that the government has become concerned with the number of explorers that have gone missing once entering a certain cave and it plans to seal the mouth of the cave. She finds a man to guide her to the cave. She makes it through but passes out.

Shalia awakens to find that the people has welcomed her as the prophesied new goddess. She accepts the role upon hearing that two prisoners await her execution. She figures the two are her brother and his partner. She devises a plan to free them and sets it in motion by calling a blacksmith.

At the appointed hour, Shelia meets the men atop a temple as her people gather below to watch the sacrifice. She tries to stab the men (who have no idea it is her) but fails. She tries a few more times but the knife leaves no mark. She convinces everyone that the men must be gods and that they should release them and throw a banquet in their honor as a means of gaining forgiveness. Only a short time later does she reveal herself to the men, along with her plan of having a knife that retracted into itself when used. They enjoy the feast.

Malu and the Fall of Zankhara

The guards climb and find Garth and Malu. Garth fights off a soldier or two but Malu is taken. She decides to fling herself and the soldier off the tower instead of being captured. Garth catches her before she falls. The two climb down and meet Gaddo, the brother of the evil queen. He is also the brother of the rival good queen, Tirza. He helps the prisoners escape through an underground door.

In Tirza, the queen Tirza welcomes Garth and Malu. Garth offers to sneak back in to Zankhara to open the gates from the inside. Gaddo agrees to help and the queen prepares her people to attack. Inside the city, Gaddo creates a diversion and lures away the gate guards. Garth opens the gate and the Tizanian soldier flood Zarkhana. The battle is fierce.

Gaddo finds his evil sister Shala and takes her captive. The city falls and Tirza awards the rule to Garth. Shala, however, knows the secret passage ways and escape. She finds a fabled boulder atop a wall and pushes it down to crush Garth and Malu. She falls with it.

Note: The series ended here without solving the question as to Sandra and Geoffry's connection to Malu and Garth. Neither does the reader know if the two escape the falling boulder.
name: Slave Girl Princess

description: The summer just got more fun with the return of The Simpsons Summer Shindig. This double-sized issue of summer-lovin' stories finds Homer, Moe, and Barney inventing a wildly popular beer donut; Santa's Little Helper and Snowball V on an incredible journey; Bart in a summer school showdown with Kearney, and much more!
name: D'Oh, Nuts!; A Roaming Holiday; Moron Kombat!

description:
• "The Lady and Her Jewels!" Green Lantern and Doiby track down a set of jewels stolen by a gangster.
  • "A Lease on Life!" Green Lantern tries to clear the name of a man framed for bank robbery.
  • "Untitled" Hop Harrigan goes on a rescue mission to save a British hospital ship attacked off the coast of Greenland.
  • "Doiby Dickles Deputy Detectives Ink." Doiby finds himself with two proteges, who help Green Lantern take down a local criminal bent on revenge.
name: The Lady and Her Jewels!; A Lease on Life!; Doiby Dickles Deputy Detectives Ink.

description:
• "The School for Vandals!" Alan inherits a school from a deceased uncle, which he uses as a front to help him take down a gangster corrupting local youths. Green Lantern created a catchphrase for the ages in this issue, with the first reading of what would become the official Green Lantern oath. Alan Scott charged his mystical ring by reciting: "In brightest day, in blackest night, no evil shall escape my sight, let those who worship evil's might, beware my power - Green Lantern's light!" Green Lantern's ring needed recharging every 24 hours and although an oath was not necessary, it added a certain gravitas to the occasion. This wasn't the first time Scott had used an oath. In his first appearance in All-American Comics #16, he had used "And I shall shed my light over dark evil, for the dark things cannot stand the light, the light of the Green Lantern!" He also tried other variations including: "My ray strikes the darkest corner, banishing all wickedness!" (All-American Comics #45, December 1942) and "As the green rays strike forth into darkness, so may all black evil be exposed and driven away!" (All-American Comics #47, February 1943). Such variety was not uncommon as creators tried to find that magical connection with readers. However, it was the "In brightest day, in blackest night" oath that proved to have true staying power, as it was resurrected by Alan Scott's successor, Hal Jordan, during the Silver Age.
  • "Love Shouldn't Happen to a Dog!" Doiby faces a dilemma when he falls for a female crook who tries to use him to destroy Green Lantern.
  • "Patsy the Punk Commits Haki Saki" Hop Harrigan challenges a notorious Japanese pilot to an aerial dual.
  • "The Tale of the Timid Terrors!" Three men with anxiety issues decide that the solution to their problems is stealing tokens unique to their desired careers, but Green Lantern disagrees.
name: The School for Vandals!; Love Shouldn't Happen to a Dog!; Patsy the Punk Commits Haki Saki; The Tale of the Timid Terrors!

description: A true Lovecraftian horror rampages through New York City. Armed with nothing but CHARLES FORT and a pair of Tesla-built Lightning guns, ATOMIC ROBO must stop THE SHADOW FROM BEYOND TIME before it swallows the world in darkness forever
name: The Doom that Came to Robo

volume.name: Atomic Robo and the Shadow From Beyond Time

description:
• "The Dastardly Designs of Doiby Dickles' Pals!" Doiby's friends betray him after being named the beneficiaries of a life insurance policy whose payout is accidentally set at one million dollars.
  • "The Mysterious Passenger!" Hop and Tank are entrusted to transport two odd travelers.
  • "Having a Wonderful Crime, Wish You Were Here" Alan writes Doiby about one of his recent adventures.
name: The Dastardy Designs of Doiby Dickles' Pals!

description:
• "It's Bad for Business!" After convincing Green Lantern to use his powers to restore a fleet of old cabs, Doiby decides to start his own taxi company.
  • "Doiby Dickles Enters High Sassiety!" Doiby enters a manner school that isn't what it seems.
  • "The Gambler!" Green Lantern and Doiby go after a new menace to the city whose trademark is his obsession for gambling.
name: It's Bad for Business!; Doiby Dickles Enters High Sassiety!; The Gambler!

description:
• "Only Green Lantern Need Apply!" Green Lantern responds to a newspaper advertisement begging for his help and is asked to help track down a lost explorer.
  • "The Lord Haw-Haw of Crime!" Green Lantern has to flush out an undercover criminal at his radio station. Meanwhile, Alan and Doiby compete for the hand of one of Alan's attractive co-workers.
  • "Da Tantrim of Green Lantrin!" Green Lantern becomes frustrated when his vacation plans are ruined by a selfish and air-headed debutante.

This is the first issue that takes place in Gotham City.
name: Only Green Lantern Need Apply!; The Lord Haw-Haw of Crime!; Da Tantrim of Green Lantrin!

description:
• "The Case of the Crooked Cook!" When Green Lantern tries to help his neighbor find a job at a local employment agency, he and Doiby uncover a plan to take over Gotham City.
  • "The Smile that Wins!" A doctor tells Alan that the best way to cure his recent stomach problems is to smile, producing unexpected consequences.
  • "The Cave Kid Goes to Town!" While vacationing out west, Alan and Doiby discover a boy living in a cave, whom they take back to Gotham until they can find out more about his past.
name: The Case of the Crooked Cook!; The Smile that Wins!; The Cave Kid Goes to Town!

description:
• "The Thoughts that Came to Life!" After an accident, Albert Zero finds himself able to make anything he thinks reality. Once Gotham City is destroyed as a result of a fleeting thought, Green Lantern must find a way to stop him from causing further damage.
  • "Carleton Congo Will Hoo-Doo You!" One of Doiby's rivals tries to gain the upper hand by consulting a witch doctor, Carleton Congo.
name: The Thoughts that Came to Life!; Carleton Congo Will Hoo-Doo You!

description:
• "The Man in the Moon" Alan and Doiby find themselves trapped on the Moon, beset by hostile tribesmen.
  • "The Lizard of Fire!" Green Lantern must battle a costumed crook who uses flammable lizards to extort local businessmen.
  • "The Jewel of Hope" Green Lantern and Doiby must foil a plot to steal a mysterious jewel from Gotham's Modern Museum.
name: The Man in the Moon; The Lizard of Fire!; The Jewel of Hope

description:
• "The Mystery of the Missing Baby Doll!" Green Lantern is wanted for robbery when he tries to steal every doll in the city.
  • "Saturn Muscles In" Alan and Doiby believe they may have find criminals from another world at a local nightclub.
  • "Quirt vs. Culture!" Depressed about his lack of culture, a local crook tries to incorporate cultural references into his criminal activity.
name: The Mystery of the Missing Baby Doll!; Saturn Muscles In; Quirt vs. Culture!

description:
• "The Last of the Buccaneers!" While Alan is on assignment in the Florida Keys, he and Doiby are attacked by a fully-manned pirate ship.
  • "The Connoisseur of Crime" Green Lantern must battle a cultivated criminal who seems intent on getting caught.
  • "The Man who Doubled in Death!" Green Lantern is on the case again when man a split personality (one good, one a crook) arrives in Gotham.
name: The Last of the Buccaneers!; The Connoisseur of Crime; The Man who Doubled in Death!

description:
• "Sing a Song of Disaster" Green Lantern investigates a series of mysteries plane crashes in the Rocky Mountains.
  • "Dickles vs. Fate" Jaded by the fact that Green Lantern gets all the credit, Doiby decides to take up a new career.
  • "Jonah was a Jinx" Green Lantern encounters a man who seems to bring bad luck with him wherever he goes.
name: Sing a Song of Disaster; Dickles vs. Fate; Jonah was a Jinx

description:
Newspaper comic strip reprints: Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Outland, Flash Gordon, Steve Canyon, Hagar the Horrible, Bloom County. Batman cover.

Also featuring the beginning of the Batman newspaper comic strip, written by Max Allan Collins ( Dick Tracy) and drawn by Marshall Rogers ( Batman: Strange Apparitions). Loosely based on the 1989 Batman movie, Batman has to not only deal with the bureaucratic obstruction of District Attorney Harvey Dent, but also a ruthless new vigilante known as the Catwoman.
name: Batman: the Catwoman, Part 1

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Tarzan, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Steve Canyon. Sky Masters by Jack Kirby and Wally Wood.
name: Casey Ruggles

description:
Newspaper comic strip reprints: Calvin and Hobbes, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Outland, Flash Gordon, Steve Canyon, Hagar the Horrible, Bloom County. Calvin and Hobbes cover.

In Batman, the Caped Crusader finally confronts the criminal-killer known as the Catwoman, who claims to have been inspired by none other than Batman himself. Can Bruce really blame himself for the creation of Catwoman? What is the real reason for her vendetta against the drug-dealing street gangs? And will Vicki Vale ever get the big scoop?
name: Batman: Catwoman, Part 2

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Tarzan by Russ Manning, Steve Canyon, Sky Masters by Jack Kirby.
name: Modesty Blaise: Tribute of the Pharoah
Modesty Blaise
Sky Masters
Tarzan
Sky Masters
Steve Canyon ; Flash Gordon

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Modesty Blaise, Bloom County, Flash Gordon, Steve Canyon, Hagar the Horrible, Popeye
name: Modesty Blaise
Topolino e il canguro di corallo
Paperino e la sagra della frittella
Topolino e i piselli sabotatori
Paperino e il turismo veloce
Paperino e le onde climatiche
Paperino e gli anelli dei dogi
Paperino e il porcellino di porcellana
Paperino intelligentone a ondate

description: Spider-Man 2009 + Spider-Man 2099 = A new era for a new hero! In this special TIMESTORM one-shot, witness the birth of the futures Spider-Man -- assuming Peter Parker, the current Spider-Man, doesn't knock some sense into him first! And if you thought Wesley Craigs art in GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY #11 & #12 was cool, just wait until he cuts loose in Marvels new 2099!

concept_credits.name: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility

first_appearance_concepts.name: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility

name: Zio Paperone e le memorie funeste
Zio Paperone e gli occhiali radioscopici

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Spider-Man, Batman, Modesty Blaise, Outland, The Phantom, Flash Gordon, Bloom County. Todd McFarlane cover.
name: Trial of the Joker, Part 1
Zio Paperone e la contessa Vanessa

description:
Newspaper comic strip reprints: Spider-Man, Batman, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Flash Gordon, Bloom County, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles

With the crime boss who murdered his parents on their trail, Dick Grayson has to keep Batman alive and escape the criminal mastermind's hideout! But little does the boy realize that the boss has the place wired to trap them inside at the press of a button, which will then trigger an explosion to destroy the entire complex and all those inside!
name: Ft. Robin, part 3, plus the TMNT!

description:
Newspaper comic strip reprints: Spider-Man, Batman, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Flash Gordon, Bloom County, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Todd McFarlane Spider-Man cover.

In the Batman comic strip: with the Batmobile on autopilot, Dick Grayson enters the Batcave for the first time, and meets a very perturbed Alfred Pennyworth. Plus: the origin of Batman!
name: Ft. Robin, Part 4
Paperino e il soggiorno esotico

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Spider-Man, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Flash Gordon, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. Featuring the start of Judge Dredd and the complete Batman Sunday strips for the Riddler storyline/
name: Judge Dredd
Paperino e le delizie della villeggiatura
Modesty Blaise in The Killing Game

description: Featuring: Tarzan of the Apes by Russ Manning, Tarzan and the Ant Men, Little Orphan Annie and Mr. Am by Harold Gray, Modesty Blaise by Peter O'Donnell and Romero, Gasoline Alley by Dick Moores, Flash Gordon by Dan Barry and Harry Harrison, The Phantom by Lee Falk, Alley Oop by V. T. Hamlin, Buz Sawyer by Roy Crane, Casey Ruggles (in color) by Warren Tufts, and Krazy Kat by George Herriman, and Steve Canyon by Milton Caniff.

name: Zio Paperone e il telesoggetto originale

description: Featuring: Modesty Blaise by O'Donnell and Romero; Gasoline Alley by Dick Moores; Flash Gordon by Harry Harrison and Dan Barry; Steve Canyon by Milton Caniff; Krazy Kat by George Herriman; Little Orphan Annie by Harold Gray; Mandrake the Magician by Falk and Davis; Alley Oop by V.T. Hamlin; Tarzan by Paul Reinman; Rick O'Shay by Stan Lynde; Buz Sawyer by Roy Crane; Casey Ruggles by Warren Tufts.
name: Lance!

description: Featuring: Modesty Blaise by O'Donnell and Romero; Gasoline Alley by Dick Moores; Flash Gordon by Harry Harrison and Dan Barry; Steve Canyon by Milton Caniff; Krazy Kat by George Herriman; Little Orphan Annie by Harold Gray; Rick O'Shay by Stan Lynde; Mandrake the Magician by Falk and Davis; Alley Oop by V.T. Hamlin; Tarzan by Paul Reinman; Buz Sawyer by Roy Crane; Casey Ruggles by Warren Tufts.

name: Flash Gordon
Paperino e l'aurite acuta
Zio Paperone monarca del bestiame

description: In the Batman comic strip, District Attorney Harvey Dent is horribly scarred by acid meant for the Joker, thrown by an unhinged loner named Jack E. Estrada. While recovering, Dent--who had already been displaying personality changes in the days before his scarring--becomes obsessed with duality and luck, with good and evil, and finds peace in the idea that he's a pawn of fate. When the bandages are removed and the horrifying extend of Dent's injuries are revealed, he decides to scar one side of the coin given to him by Bruce, to ensure that he can now take fate into his own hands. He then attempts to come forward with the wire-tapping, his duplicitous assistant blackmails Harvey into staying silent, and letting the assistant take over as the new D.A., not realizing that the man he's trying to threaten is no longer Harvey Dent, but Two-Face.
name: Modesty Blaise
Zio Paperone e il deposito semovente
Topolino aviatore dello Yantukian

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Judge Dredd , Spider-Man, Tarzan, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Flash Gordon, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, B.C.
name: Doctor Strange & The Amazing Spider-Man

description: Newspaper comic strip reprints: Spider-Man, Tarzan, Modesty Blaise, The Phantom, Steve Canyon. Sky Masters by Jack Kirby and Wally Wood.
name: Modesty Blaise in Honeygun
Zio Paperone e l'oroscopo elettronico
Paper Wotan e la pesca del crepuscolo
Paperino e i guanti strabilianti
Aladdin
Topolino 2000

description:
• "Shadow of the Past" Green Lantern encounters a man given three months to live who decides to return to his former criminal ways for the sake of his son.
  • [Untitled]. Doiby explains to the reader how Alan got to be responsible for so many jobs at WXYZ.
  • "The Gambler Comes Back" The Gambler escapes from prison by disguising himself as Doiby, and Green Lantern vows to the warden to catch him.
name: Shadows of the Past; Untitled; The Gambler Comes Back

description:
• "The Woodman" Green Lantern and Doiby find themselves searching for treasure on the property of an eccentric old man who built everything in his house out of wood.
  • "The Good Humor Man" A strange man has paid a group of criminals to do anything to make him angry, even if it means crossing Green Lantern.
  • "What Makes Goitrude Go?" When Doiby's cab, Goitrude, suddenly becomes able to drive faster, Doiby finds himself forced into a gang.
name: The Woodman; The Good Humor Man; What Makes Goitrude Go?

description:
• "The Old-Fashioned Way" Green Lantern faces a recently released criminal who refuses to use any technology developed since he went to prison in 1911.
  • "The Man Who Insults Everybody" Doiby and Green Lantern must help a man with a propensity for insulting everyone acquire his rightful inheritance before gangsters can get to it first.
  • "The Invisible World" When Doiby's goldfish vanish into a smaller world, Green Lantern must use his power ring to shrink himself down and investigate the mystery.
name: The Old-Fashioned Way; The Man Who Insults Everybody; The Invisible World

description:
• "Doiby Dickles Da Stunt Man" Doiby becomes a stunt man to replace a man who almost dies during filming, only to nearly become the victim of several suspicious accidents himself.
  • "The Man Who Went Back" WXYZ's richest stockholder decides to sell out and move to a community that uses only technology from the 1890s. When he arrives, however, he finds that the past is not as golden as he remembers.
  • "Long Live Da King!" Doiby volunteers to pose as a foreign prince to help foil a plot by an evil aristocrat.
name: Doiby Dickles Da Stunt Man; The Man Who Went Back; Long Live Da King!

description:
• "Once a Cop" Green Lantern and Doiby come between a 25-year-old feud involving a retired police chief and an escaped criminal he put away.
  • "Happy Boithday!" The birthday festivities for Goitrude, Doiby's taxi, go awry after a wealthy collector offers to buy her.
  • "Indestructible Jones!" Three hoods try to collect on a $10,000 life insurance policy they took out an a bum by killing him, but Green Lantern has other ideas.
name: Once a Cop; Happy Boithday!; Indestructible Jones!

description:
• "The Diamond Magnet!" Local gangsters conscript a kleptomaniac who attracts diamonds to his body like a magnet, but they must confront Green Lantern before their scheme can succeed.
  • "The Man who Couldn't Win!" Green Lantern crusades against an illegal gambling outfit outside of Gotham's city limits, with the help of a man who seems to have no luck.
  • "The Man Behind the Mask!" A sophisticated criminal named the Fop begins a crime spree by taking advantage of his position in Gotham's aristocracy.
name: The Diamond Magnet!; The Man who Couldn't Win!; The Man Behind the Mask!

description:
• "The Scourge of the Seas!" Green Lantern investigates a series of reported ship disappearances at the hands of a sea monster in the North Atlantic.
  • "The Flood Maker!" Dr. Aqua, a scientist who can create rain and floods at his own whim, has decided to flood a local town to further his own ends, but first he must fight Green Lantern.
  • "The Song that Spelled Out Disaster" Doiby is mistaken for a long-lost singer when one of his fares sings in front of an opera conductor.
name: The Scourge of the Seas!; The Flood Maker!; The Song that Spelled Out Disaster
